name: Concept: Workflow with Conditional Execution using "Numeric Value Check GW Automation"
description: This is a concept runbook that delivers and uses the GW_NumericValChk automation.

steps.description:
This is a sample runbook provided to show the concept of reacting on some incident by executing some action (via SCRIPT) on an arbitrary  number of endpoint systems.

This runbook shows how to conditionally execute automations in a step.



As runbook steps this is translated to::

• (Start) Step 2 Find affected Systems
→ Step 3 Calculate how many system
→ Step 4 Get list of hostname with "Linux" systems affected.
♦ (Condition) Step 5 Use GW Automation as condition to create target list with [0..n] hostnames.
Use as Input results calculated in Step 3 and Step 4
→ (Conditional) Step 6 Sample automation that runs on all systems prepared in step 5
Use (0..n) target(s) calculated in Step 5
× (End)

This first step typically uses an automation that checks a certain condition highlighted by the incident. It finds target systems to be changed/ fixed by a following automation.

This automation simply prints a list of <OS> <HOSTNAME> <A_COMPONENT> out.
It is just for demo purposes to show the concept. If you want to use this runbook and run in you environment than you have to edit this automation and add a list of real HOSTNAMES to be printed instead.

Notice: Do not skip execution of this automation - the result of this automation is being used as input for the automations in Step 3 and Step 4..

Remember: The systems represented by the HOSTNAMES must be be prepared with the SSH Key required for script automation.

Handle Incident

This step uses the output of previous step to create a Key=Value list for the GW Automation in next step.
If the Automation in previous step is already able to provide this Key=Value list then this automation can be omitted.

Notice: Do not skip execution of this automation - the result of this automation is being used as one input of the Gateway Automation in step 5.

Calc Patch Systems by OS

Now, in this step compile the list of Linux systems to be checked
Notice: Do not skip execution of this automation - the result of this automation is being used as one input of the Gateway Automation in step 5.
 

Get System Names by OS

This step calls the Automation to create a list of targets that can be used by following "Multi-Target-Automations".

Notice: The concept of an automation that calculates a target list (which can be even empty) is called "Gateway Automation".
Since Gateway Automation decides to either return a filled or an empty list of target - you can use it for conditional execution of automations in following steps.

GW_NumericValChk

Run the following automation to check for installed package PACKAGENAME on the target list, which is calculated in step before

Notice: The following script automation is being called with a list of targets calculated in previous steps.
This concept is called "Multi Target Automation".

Therefore the script in this automation will be executed in parallel on all the specified targets.
In case where the list of target calculated by the automation in step before is empty - the automation will not be executed on any system, but still end with status "successfull"

Display Package Info

parameters.name: PACKAGENAME
parameters.description: This is the package name to be checked with yum

§§exportedAutomation_0_§§.name: GW_NumericValChk
§§exportedAutomation_0_§§.description:
This gateway automation can be called with an array of arbitrary length in the form of <key>=<value>:<key2>=<value2>:<key3>=<value3>: ...
For example INPUT="tomatoes=12:apples=23:strawberries=18:peach=33"

The input of this form can be checked for a specified <key> <operand> <value>
For example KEY="apples" OPER=">"  VALUE="15"

In addition a comma-separated list of target systems (endpoints / EPS) can be specified 
For example EPS="linuxprod001,linuxprod002,windowsprod010,aixprod111"

If the check evaluates to "true" the specified list of EPS is returned as array suitable as target for a following automation.
In the above example the number of apples is bigger then 15, which results in following array to be written to the standard output:
[linuxprod001,linuxprod002,windowsprod010,aixprod111]

If an unknown KEY is specified or the combination of OPER and VALUE evaluated to "false" an empty array is written to the standard output
such as "[]

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: Target system where the script will be executed

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: User ID that is used to run the script

parameters.name: $INPUT
parameters.description: This is the array of <key>=<value> separated by ":" to be checked

parameters.name: $KEY
parameters.description: This is the KEY to be checked in the INPUT array

parameters.name: $OPER
parameters.description: This is the operator to be used in the value check

parameters.name: $VALUE
parameters.description: This is the value to be used in the value check

parameters.name: $EPS
parameters.description: This is the comma-separated list of endpoint systems to be returned as array when this GW automation evaluated to TRUE

§§exportedAutomation_1_§§.name: Handle Incident
§§exportedAutomation_1_§§.description: This is an automation that shows a Linux package to be change, since a some problem has been identified with it.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: Target system where the script will be executed

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: User ID that is used to run the script

parameters.name: $PACKAGE
parameters.description: This is the package to be Fixed

§§exportedAutomation_2_§§.name: Calc Patch Systems by OS
§§exportedAutomation_2_§§.description: This returns the number of systems to be pathched by OS

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: Target system where the script will be executed

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: User ID that is used to run the script

§§exportedAutomation_3_§§.name: Get System Names by OS
§§exportedAutomation_3_§§.description: Get a list of Systems of a specific OS. Input is an array with line "<OS> <SYSName> <INFO>"

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: Target system where the script will be executed

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: User ID that is used to run the script

§§exportedAutomation_4_§§.name: Display Package Info
§§exportedAutomation_4_§§.description: This automation simply uses "yum" to display the information of the package which has been specified by parameter.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: Target system where the script will be executed

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: User ID that is used to run the script

parameters.name: $PACKAGE
parameters.description: The name of the package to be checked
